headline: Tomatillo Salsa Verde
description: This authentic Mexican salsa verde has a fabulous flavor. Use it on chicken enchiladas or as a condiment for any dish that needs a little extra zip!

video.description: Vibrant condiment sauce made with tomatillos.
video.name: Tomatillo Salsa Verde

name: Tomatillo Salsa Verde

recipeInstructions.text: Place tomatillos, onion, chile pepper, and garlic into a large saucepan; season with cilantro, oregano, salt, and cumin. Pour in water and bring to a boil over high heat; reduce heat to medium-low and simmer until the tomatillos are soft, 10 to 15 minutes.
Transfer tomatillo mixture into a blender in batches; puree until smooth.

review.reviewBody: There's absolutely no doubt about it. Way too much water in this recipe. If you follow this recipe, you may waste your first batch because it's tomatillo soup instead of tomatillo sauce. The oregano is just weird, too. I didn't like the flavor of this recipe. My wife kept asking me why I was putting in Oregano, and I took some out. I didn't remove enough. I give it two stars. If I didn't strain the water out, it would have been a 1 star "couldn't eat it".
Don't need all that water. The toms have plenty. Much thicker and chunkier.
Yummy, an easy
I just made it and I love it! Will keep this for a basic use as I have been wanting a salsa that is easy. Thank you Kathryn
Flavor is decent, but needs lime juice. And you should cut the water in half if you want this to be a salsa. 2 cups of water makes this a soup.
Loved it and ate it all day!
My peppers weren't spicy enough, but it was easy to make and delicious. Just not spicy.

I made this salsa for use in a different recipe. A friend had given me home grown tomatillos . This salsa verde was great and made the chicken and sweet potato chili thatvI made so much better than using a jar!

I used Nina's advice to omit all the water and I use the food processor instead of a blender. And one other person who said to add a quarter cup of lime juice. I didn't have any fresh red pepper so I used some dried crushed red pepper I made from 
piquin chili pepper. Fantastic!

I blend down all my ingredients and then I simmer it in a saucepan for 20 minutes on low. Less burn risk ;) It turns out amazing. Jalapenos or hot hatch green chilies will also work in place of the serrano pepper. I've tried both in separate batches and found no flavor issues.

This is the secret sauce in my chicken enchiladas. Instead of simmer, I cook on medium and add in 2 - 8 oz. packages of cream cheese. Stir the mix until it's bubbly and smooth. Add some in your enchiladas and pour the rest over the top. Since discovering this sauce, my family demands chicken enchiladas weekly. I've negotiated a compromise for every other week. LOL!

After reading reviews, I decided the original recipe was going to be too watery. So I roughly chopped the tomatillos and sauteed all the ingredients in a little olive oil without adding any water. For the last 10 minutes, I covered the pot and just let them simmer gently. Then I ran them through the blender. The result was perfect. 

I also adjusted the seasonings based on what I had: 1/2 tsp ground coriander since I didn't have cilantro, 2 tsp dried oregano instead of the fresh, and 2 pinches red pepper flakes plus a sprinkle of black pepper in place of the whole pepper. It was quite tasty!

Definitely should have tried roasting instead of boiling the ingredients. It was rather bland overall and needed some doctoring - more lime and garlic. Maybe it was the tomatillos, but I found the recipe really lacked the zing of a green salsa.

The only changes to the original recipe was that I subbed fresh oregano for 1/2 tsp ground, used 1/2 of a large poblano pepper instead of the serrano and used only 1 cup veggie stock instead water. It was authentic and delicious!
My family loves this so much!

I made this it was simple and delicious! I made a small batch for hubby and I. Love the smell while cooking ingredients brings to the house. I added lime like others suggested. Otherwise, I used ingredients as listed for recipe.
Excellent - refreshing and crisp flavours!
I used ancho chile instead of the serrano to give it a slightly richer flavor and it did. Great recipe!

This is yummy! I followed the recommendations of other cooks. I roasted the tomatillos and peppers first, then pureed. For my approx. 5 pounds of tomatillos (photo is about 2/3 of tomatillos), the roasting removed a quart of liquid. I added 3 Hungarian yellow peppers (look like poblanos) and 3 serannos. I also added 3/4 C vinegar and about 1/4 C lime juice. Yielded 7 pints once canned (water bath for 15 min).
Loved the recipe. Here’s what I did differently. I roasted all the veggies and added extra cilantro. Made 15 pints. Will definitely use this recipe again next year!

Excellent. Blended everything first as suggested and no water was needed. Instead of chile peppers I put in a 1/2 teaspoon of cayenne pepper which I added while heating in skillet. I also added juice from half a lime then refrigerated until ready to use. I've made it this way 5x already, always get compliments.
I liked the flavor but the recipe calls for WAYYY too much water. I put 3 cups in 5 lbs of tomatillos and it was still too much. Tomatillos are mostly water - a 1/2 c would probably be plenty.
I used one dried habanero instead of serrano and it turned out amazing. Just the right amount of spice and flavor.

Delicious. Could not stop eating out of the blender. Roasted the tomatillos on bbq grill while cooking chicken. Added 2 roasted jalapeños for a little more kick. This will be in regular rotation for sure.
Delicious! I blended the ingredients before I cooked them as others suggested and it was wonderful. I put it on pork chops, chicken and used it as a dip. So easy to make.
I had a few tomatillos and didn't know what to do with them. Making this salsa couldn't have been easier and it is delicious!!
I made per the recipe, changing nothing. Way too watery. I like salsa to stay on a chip. This wouldn't. Would use no more than one cup of water, maybe less.
I made per the recipe, changing nothing. Way too watery. I like salsa to stay on a chip. This wouldn't. Would use no more than one cup of water, maybe less.
I followed the recipe exactly and wouldn’t change a thing. My husband couldn’t stop dipping chips into the bowl before it had even cooled! I can’t wait to try it with chicken and shrimp.
Made recipe as is first. Then second time, followed advice to blend first, add lime juice, and not water. Honestly, it is rather bland. Maybe third time is a charm, but I think I'll keep looking.

Thank you for this recipe. My first time making salsa and wonderful results. Like others, I roasted the tomatillos and peppers and blended everything before simmering in a saucepan. No water was needed for my preferred consistency. I used jalapeno pepper due to lack of serrano and added a very small amount of fresh ground arbol powder to fire it up a little further.
Love this! Easy to make, too. Thanks for a great recipe.
This was an easy recipe to follow. Super simple. We did triple the peppers, we love a bit of heat.

This was so good! I made pretty much to the recipe. (I only had a few tomatilloes, used fresh garlic, etc... so didn't really measure) I decided to put everything on my roasting pan since I was blistering some peppers anyway, then threw it all into the blender, then condensed down to where I wanted on the stove. Easy Perfection!

I used ninas recommendations as using blender first , it was watery but after being in the fridge it thickened up .though I did not use bullion as she recommended . I did use a plash of lime . I found mine to be very salty ,so I tried adding some sugar , that made no difference .I had some cooked rice in the fridge and added it ,, and it softened the saltiness and made it very scoop able ...next time I will cut back on the salt

I've made this salsa twice now. Ingredients should say seedless serrano chili pepper. After it's all done simmering I don't blend with any water because the tomatillos make enough juice to blend. I just use a big plastic spoon with holes to get everything out of the pot and place in blender. I let the salsa sit out and cool down before placing in the fridge. After an hour and around dinner time it's cool enough to eat. It's so good! My husband loves this recipe! Thank you for sharing!
This is the most consistently good and popular recipe I make. I usually make it right before the party starts and serve it warm with chips- good every time!
To much water. So I left some out before I blended. also added 1/2 a lime. Will make again....... but with less water.
Yummy best ever!!!!
I'm not use to eating Tomatillos and didn't like it but other people did enjoy the salsa. I'll use the salsa as a marinated for meats.
I added one jalapeno pepper along with the serrano pepper. Aside from that, I followed the recipe exactly and it turned out delicious!
I needed to add in additional cumin and salt after blended to bring those flavors up a little. And a tbsp of vinegar never hurts to brighten up flavors.

I used 3 Serrano peppers and I roasted all vegetables prior to making the sauce. I also substituted fresh ground pink himalayan salt for table salt. It is Chicken Fajita night in house and this homemade salsa verde is gping to be a huge hit!
I add 1/2 cup of sugar and use less water so that it's thicker. I use an immersion blender after it's cooked about 30 minutes. I use this as a relish.

Took some of the commenting advice and blended all the ingredients first without the water. It makes enough of its own, I added a touch of white vinegar too and cooked it all aster blending. Delicious! Will definitely make again; however, I will roast the tomatillos first as I know it will have even more flavor.

Only changed the recipe a little bit. Used some chicken broth to cook down the tomatillos, onions, garlic and peppers. Then threw an entire bunch of cilantro in the mix, followed by a lot of fresh oregano. Simmer then put in the blue Nader. Used it as the sauce for Pork Verde. It turned out amazing!
This stuff is crazy good, I only made it to make my wife happy, now I don't want to share. LOL

Good basic verde recipe that easily lends itself to modification. My suggestion... don’t add the water! I put all the ingredients (coarse chopped) NO WATER in a food processor and blend together and pour into a sauce pan to heat. Fresh oregano, cilantro and garlic is a must. I add lime juice after the cooking process. Absolutely delicious on chicken enchiladas with cojita cheese!!
I put this over chicken enchiladas and baked them. It was wonderful. Everyone loved it! Tangy, and not hot, very flavorful.

I blended all the ingredients before boiling/simmering on the stove top. I added the juice from a lime, used two serrano chile peppers instead of one, and I didn't add oregano. I didn't add the water until after blending, and I used one cup instead of two. I will definitely make this again. Next time I might add the oregano; I simply didn't have fresh oregano on hand. It was flavorful with a subtle kick.

I made this to use some tomatillos from our garden and I only had 4 so I halved the recipe. I followed the advice of other reviewers and used lime juice, skipped the water, and blended everything in a food processor first. This is so delicious I decided to grow more tomatillos next year! Thanks!

I read others reviews and this is how I rolled; I put the tomatillos and one jalapeno in the food processor and processed until smooth. I then added this to the pan and added juice of one lime, 1tsp cumin, 2 teaspoons chicken bullion, 1 tsp of dried Mexican oregano, 1tsp of white vinegar and cooked on low for 20 min. I let it cool and added a tbs of fresh finely chopped cilantro. From here on this will be my go to tomatillo salsa
No changes. I will be making this again with my homegrown tomatillos and peppers
Taste was great but way too watery. Have to Use a mesh strainer to drain out the extra liquid or it would’ve been soup.
This was easy, fun and delicious! It got an A+ even from my most critical taste tester.

What a great recipe, I changed just about everything.
Added lime and more cumin and yes.. I'm being sarcastic after reading all the other reviews.
Reduce salt to 1/2 teaspoon
Use 1/4 to 1/2 cup less water because your adding 5-8 roasted jalapenos and 2-3 roasted pasilla peppers. Adding peppers creates more liquid.

I made this following the directions and it came out quite thin and a little bland (but spicy!). Added a little vinegar and lime juice and some more garlic and boiled off some of the liquid. Would definitely add water as needed next time rather than adding it all up front.
Delicious! But too much water - I cut it to 1 cup and it's still too watery. But easily adjusted.
Excellent recipe. I added 1/4 of a Poblano pepper, 1T lime juice and left the Serrano pepper whole for a little kick.
It is a flavour bomb. I was pleasantly surprised and it was very easy to make
I did not make any changes . This is the best receipt for Salsa verde de Tomatillo. My favorite and my families.
Great recipe. Was my first try at tomatillo salsa and came out terrific. I used a jalapeno instead of a serrano but otherwise followed the recipe exactly. Will be making again for sure.
Loved it!!
Great recipe to tweak to your personal tastes. I used half a Serrano and it was too spicy for my mild tastes. Half the salt was good for me. Simmered everything in half chicken stock and half water.

Easy to make and delicious - even our girlie loved it! Simple salsa that you can up the heat factor by adding and extra pepper if you want - but our family enjoyed it as per the recipe. Will make again.
Followed the directions as written, but increased the roast time to 15 to 17 minutes. Great flavor and super easy. Thank you for sharing!

Great recipe , made as instructed. 
Thank you
Too watery and flavor was too sour. :-(

Everyone liked it. I did pay attention to the helpful hints and therefore deviated by 1) blending before cooking to reduce water, 2) replaced water with chicken broth - no vegans here, 3) added a touch of cumin. Overall, this is a good recipe. Look forward to adding some simmered chunky onions and mild peppers to the mixture and using it to smother burritos!
Refreshing, delicious. Serve it all

I made this tonight. I didn't have full amount of tomatillos so reduced water some and added a tomato that needed using. I put in about 1/4 cup lime juice and extra onion. And used 2 habaneros. It was a bit watery so I added some chia seeds to each bottle while they were still cooling. My friend, who loves habanero anything, just texted me to say it is really good. (I just finished it before she left my house and it was still warm.) I moved to Mexico from US a year ago and developing my pallet for hotter peppers. I do like the flavor and will continue to make this with some of the modifications suggested by others.

I made a half batch just in case we didn't like it. I've had some really good green salsa at restaurants but, never made any myself. I've also never used tomatillos before either. Other than halfing the most of the ingredients, I used two Serrano peppers instead of one. My wife and I both like it. I've added it to chicken, fish, and steak. Next time we have fajitas, this is definitely going on them.

This is a great recipe. We like our salsa with body, so I sometimes double the garlic and add half raw just before mixing it all up. I’ve also roasted peppers and added them at the end. You can lemon it up too. Great as a dip or a cooking sauce for chicken, beef or pork. A classic!
Perfect....but I followed Nina's tip. I have made tomatillo salsa before and this is easier and less watery.

If you make this salsa using NINA L.'s review (the first one where she tells you how to blend it), you would be making a HUGE mistake if you didn't double the recipe! This is perfection! I bought some jalapenos that I needed to use up and found this recipe, but they didn't have any zip at all, so I added a serrano pepper. This wasn't at all spicy, but the flavor is yummy. I made some enchiladas and used this. I think that tomorrow I'll make some eggs for breakfast and use up the last of the salsa. Thanks for this recipe! My husband thanks you, too!
I wish people would stop giving 5 stars for a recipe they changed. This is way too watery. I should have read the reviews first.
no changes except reducing the amount of water. My husband says this is better anything you can buy!
Delicious!!! I also blended the ingredients first and boiled without water. Also added some lime like some mention.
delicious and easy, I should have used only one cup of water and added more as needed

LOVE IT!! Feels like I am at my fave mexican restaurant. Personal note, when it says to blend in batches. DO IT!! I filled my blender 1/2 way and that was too full. Salsa everywhere! Lesson learned. Will be making this again and again!

I took the advice of "Nina L." and blended the ingredients (with the exclusion of the cilantro and oregano) together first...shortening the cooking time by a lot and reached the perfect consistency without having to guess. I cooked the mixture almost dry. I took more advice from "Judy" and added 1/2 c. of fresh lime juice at the end with the cilantro and oregano. All the modifications were to suit my family's likes....the recipe is great just as is. Thanks Kimberly Binning! I never try a recipe with out consulting the reviews. FANTASTIC modifications ladies!
So easy and delicious

I don’t like spicy so I picked the seeds out of the hot peppers. I took the suggestion of blending everything before cooking. I didn’t add ANY water and I thought it was perfect consistency. I did go shy on the salt but countered with a little chicken Better Than Bouillon. I wish I had lime on hand.
So easy and delicious!

While this is very good, I think that cooking the onions, cilantro, etc. beforehand is not necessary. I actually think adding them after the tomaillos are cooked enhances the flavor of the entire dish.
Good stuff-Real easy to make! Makes about 3 pint jars if you're wondering.
Omg I love this salsa! My husband loved it too

I made this using tomatillos from my garden- I blended the tomatillos, garlic, onion and peppers in my blender. Added no water, but added about 1/3 C. lime juice (had 3 1/2 lb tomatillos so adjusted the recipe accordingly) and a splash of vinegar. Brought to a boil and simmered for 15 minutes. This is really good! It made 1/2 of a dutch oven pot. I hope to harvest a lot more tomatillos and can some of this in pints- yummy!
So good. We had it over grilled chicken breasts and rice

As I was making this salsa it smelled amazing! I used half of the water mentioned in the recipe and jalapeño pepper (seeded & deveined) instead. It was a tad bit spicy but overall good. A little watery even with using half of the water recommended. I would recommend simmering it to the desired consistency and adding some lime juice for added flavor. Otherwise a good salsa verde.
Made this with only one change. Used jalapeno pepper and turned out delicious. Definitely making again
Made loved it

WOW! What a great salsa! Holy Moly... I have actually never made salsa before. I got a ton of tomatillos from a produce co-op that I participate in so decided to try it. Usually I will go through all the reviews to see what others have tried & this time was no different. I washed & quartered all the tomatillos (about 3ish lbs) then added them directly to the saucepan. Then I rough chopped a whole white onion, 2 large garlic cloves, 2 jalapeños (seeds & membranes & all), a handful of fresh cilantro & oregano. Then I added 2 heaping teaspoons of cumin & a tablespoon of my favorite Tastefully Simple season salt. Brought the whole pot to a boil, then simmered until everything was soft & reduced. Emersion blendered the entire batch & VOILA! What an amazing salsa - the whole family agreed! No water or vinegar needed. Will definitely be making this again. Thank you!!

Roasted the tomatillos and onions slightly before cooking them with much less water along with the chili, and drained and cooled the mix before adding the spices and half a bunch of cilantro (no oregano) and blending them with the juice and zest of half a lime; that way it's not all overcooked watery mush.

Result was a lovely fresh tasting (and looking) salsa that wasn't watery or soupy. 

The draining gave more control over the consistency and texture of the salsa, depending on preference. Kept the drained liquid and added it to a homemade tomato sauce.
Needs lime juice. Roast veggies & garlic in oven for more flavor. Otherwise easy to make and good flavor. I used three jalapeños as I already had some leftover from something else.
My first run was too watery for my taste, so I just used 3/4 of the recommended amount of water and it was perfect.

I recently made this recipe, following it mostly. The resulting taste was excellent, but the consistency was very watery (also noted by other reviewers). So this turned out to be a great Mexican sauce for a dinner, but not a great sals.

Here are the changes I made: I did not have the serrano chili, but I did have dried New Mexico chilis, so I reconstituted one of those in a half cup hot water. I then substituted that 1/2 cup of chili flavored water for a 1/2 cup of the plain water called for in the ingredients. Lastly, I used dried oregano rather than fresh because that's what I had on hand.

Like I said, it's great flavor, but watery so it makes a sauce, not a salsa. To make a salsa, I'd reduce the water to 1/2 cup to start, only adding more water as it cooks if it appears too thick.

Good recipe, but I added a few things to my own taste. If you don't like the wateryness of this recipe, try adding a couple avocados and cutting the 2 cups of water. Tomatillos are naturally watery anyways.
